awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Deformations in statistics, cosmology and image analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
Smooth invertible transformations, or deformations, are fast becoming important tools in modern data analysis. The nonlinear nature of deformations makes these objects extremely powerful while at the same time making them challenging to estimate and theoretically explore. This proposal is dedicated to the development and theoretical understanding of deformations applied to three specific areas of research: statistics, cosmology and image analysis. The theoretical properties of estimated deformations for generating nonparametric and semiparametric statistical estimates are analyzed through a surprising connection with Stein's method. In addition, the investigator focuses on recent results found in the theory of optimal transport, which has the potential to provide a rigorous theoretical foundation for deformable templates. The computational aspects of estimated deformations will utilize a new Euler-Lagrange characterization of a penalized maximum likelihood estimate, which can significantly relieve the typical computational burden associated with estimation. One consequence will be to make these methods available for widespread use by statistical practitioners in a broad range of problems: nonparametric and semiparametric density estimation, estimating gravitational lensing in cosmology and posterior sampling techniques, to name a few. Another intellectual merit of this proposal are the scientific ramifications of two new proposed deformation estimates of weak lensing of the cosmic microwave background (CMB): a wavelet/Slepian quadratic estimator and a new Bayesian lensing estimator. Gravitational lensing studies have become one of the most successful tools for probing the nature of dark matter. The precise estimation of lensing is important for a number of reasons including, but not limited to, understanding cosmic structure, constraining cosmological parameters and detecting gravity waves. The investigator proposes to uses wavelets and Slepian multi-tapers to adapt the quadratic estimate to local foreground contaminants and sky cuts, which are ubiquitous features in most modern cosmological surveys. The investigator proposes a new Bayesian estimator which has the potential to dramatically change the way gravitational lensing studies are done and how they are integrated within other astronomical surveys.

Smooth invertible transformations, or deformations, are fast becoming important tools in modern data analysis.  They have been used with spectacular success in the field of computational anatomy where time varying vector field flows which generate deformations are used to statistically analyze medical fMRI images and quantify abnormal morphological structure. In cosmology, deformations are used to model gravitational distortions of the cosmic microwave background from dark matter density fluctuations, and have resulted in a deeper understanding of cosmic structure. Even though these important tools are becoming integrated in modern scientific methods, the statistical properties of estimated deformations have been largely unexplored. This proposal is dedicated to the development and theoretical understanding of deformations applied to three specific areas of research: statistics, cosmology and image analysis. The tools resulting from this project will be useful, not only in statistics, but also in other branches of science and technology ranging from genetics to machine learning. In the field of physics, for example, the potential scientific progress resulting from gravitational lensing estimation could a have broad impact on scientific understanding and the future of scientific research. Moreover, it is becoming increasingly important to train graduate and undergraduate students with the tools necessary to successfully navigate interdisciplinary work, and who are prepared for independent research. The interdisciplinary nature of the proposal will foster a culture of collaboration that will reach the fundamentals of statistical education and will deepen ties with statistics and other physical sciences. In addition, through the integration of research and education, the proposal will teach both graduate and undergraduate students research skills. The result will be two fold. First, it will train graduate students to become creative independent researchers who can contribute within an academic environment. Second, it will educate undergraduates to navigate a work environment which values creative independent investigation.

por.por_cntn:
The most significant outcome of the project centers around the development of a full joint Bayesian analysis of the Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) polarization and gravitational lensing. This is a multiyear effort culminating in two papers---titled "Optimal CMB Lensing Reconstruction and Parameter Estimation with SPTpol Data" and "Sampling based inference of the primordial CMB and gravitational lensing"--- that develop and subsequently deploy the first simultaneous Bayesian parameter inference and optimal reconstruction of the gravitational lensing of the CMB on 100 square degrees of polarization observations from the SPTpol receiver on the South Pole Telescope. The Bayesian sampler along with some of the key techniques developed to solve it (such as LenseFlow and the MixFlow re-parameterization) are not exclusive to the particular application of gravitational lensing and have potential to impact a broad range of cosmological applications and change the landscape of how the science is done and perhaps just as important, how experimental deliverables are packaged for access by the general public and for scientists harnessing the information from one experiment to another.

In addition to the theoretical development and scientific application of Bayesian lensing analysis the project also demonstrated the power of new coding technologies that were developed as part of this project, such as GPU acceleration and new open source software (called CMBLensing.jl), which enabled a broad range of testing and prototyping capabilities. The flexibility afforded by this system is invaluable to the type of quick exploration which is necessary for developing methodology in increasingly complex datasets. This package should serve as a useful tool for the CMB lensing community and a broad range of practitioners.

A second major outcome of the project was the discovery that a new continuum resistance metric on graphs with Euclidean edges resolves all the apparent degeneracy of the class of positive definite radial functions with respect to the geodesic metric. The significance of this new metric is that many of the commonly used isotropic covariance functions in the spatial statistics literature are valid with respect to this new resistance metric on any linear network. This is in stark contrast to the geodesic metric where even the basic exponential auto-covariance model fails to be positive semi-definite at all range scales when the graph contains three distinct paths connecting two points.

This completes a key objective for developing valid covariance models on linear networks which are isotropic with respect to a metric on the network. The work is published in the paper titled ?Isotropic covariance functions on graphs and their edges? and allows statisticians to model random fields on complex graphs such as river and streets networks. These results have real implications for inference and estimation. As an illustration, consider the practitioner who models random fields on street networks. The results developed by this project show that if these practitioners attempted to apply some of the commonly used covariance models with the geodesic metric, their covariance models could become non-positive semi-definite, possibly exposing their prediction code to extreme errors such as negative variances and corrupted parameter estimation, potentially leading to real cost in terms of time, money or physical safety depending on how the results are used. The results in the paper identify these risks (when using a geodesic metric for developing covariance matrices) and show that they can be circumvented by replacing the geodesic metric with the new continuum resistance metric whereby guaranteeing the validity of the common covariance models used in spatial statistics and their associated likelihood methods.

A third line of investigation for this project is in the area of deformable templates in image analysis. The main result is reported in the paper titled "Discrete Wasserstein Barycenters: Optimal transport for discrete data" which derives an extension of theoretical results of Agueh and Carlier to the case where the individual probability measures are supported on a finite subset. The results closely mirror those found in the absolutely continuous case with a few exceptions. For example, the Wasserstein barycenter can be shown to always exist but it may not be unique. Surprisingly, however, there still exists an optimal transport characterization of the barycenter. One consequence of this transportation result is that the finite barycenter, derived in this project, also satisfies the deformable template minimization criterion. Indeed, optimal transports do not typically exists between two finite measures which makes barycenters special in this regard. A surprising outcome of these results is an upper bound on the support size of a discrete Wasserstein Barycenter which shows that optimal barycenter is supported on an extremely restricted set of observations points. This  shows that there is potential for restricting the huge number of variables in the full linear programing characterization of the optimal barycenter.
